facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2321 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated 1st November 1968 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Civil Miscellaneous Appeal No. 111 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2321 of 1968. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 1st November, 1968 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Civil Miscella

facts.text: Pratap Singh, Preetam Singh and Diwan Singh are three brothers.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by C. SHAH, AG. C.J. Pratap Singh, Preetam Singh and Diwan Singh are three brothers.

facts.text: Pratap Singh and Preetam Singh carried on business in partnership at Pipliya in Madhya Pradesh in the name of Jaora Slate Pencil Works.

anchor.surface_text: Pratap Singh and Preetam Singh carried on business in partnership, at three places- Pipliya in Madhya Pradesh, in the name of the Jaora Slate Pencil Works

facts.text: Pratap Singh and Preetam Singh carried on business in partnership at Bombay in the name of Partap Brothers.

anchor.surface_text: 2  Bombay, in the name of Partap Brothers and

facts.text: Pratap Singh and Preetam Singh carried on business in partnership at Nagpur in the name of Nice Tiles and Marble, Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: 3  Nagpur, in the name of Nice Tiles and Marble, Nagpur. By an agreement dated December 18, 1965 disputes between Pratap Singh and Preetam Singh relating to the partnership business were referred to the arbitration of their brother Diwan Singh.

facts.text: By an agreement dated December 18, 1965 disputes between Pratap Singh and Preetam Singh relating to the partnership business were referred to the arbitration of Diwan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement dated December 18, 1965 disputes between Pratap Singh and Preetam Singh relating to the partnership business were referred to the arbitration of their brother Diwan Singh.

facts.text: Diwan Singh entered upon the arbitration reference but was unable to complete it within four months.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator entered upon the reference, but he was unable to companyplete the reference within four months.

facts.text: Diwan Singh applied to the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Delhi under s. 28 of the Arbitration Act for extension of time.

anchor.surface_text: Diwan Singh applied to the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Delhi, under s. 28 of the Arbitration Act for extension of time.

facts.text: Preetam Singh objected to the jurisdiction of the Subordinate Judge at Delhi to entertain the application.

anchor.surface_text: Preetam Singh objected to the jurisdiction of the Subordinate Judge at Delhi to entertain the application.

facts.text: The Subordinate Judge overruled the objection and granted extension of time for making the award.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge overruled the objection and granted extension of time for making the award.

facts.text: A revision application against the Subordinate Judge's order is pending before the High Court of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: A revision application preferred against the order is pending before the High Court of Delhi.

facts.text: Preetam Singh filed an action in the Court of the Additional District Judge, Mandsaur against Pratap Singh and Pritipal Singh for a decree for rendition of accounts of Jaora Slate Pencil Works and for appointment of a receiver.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile Preetam Singh filed an action in the Court of the Additional District Judge, Mandsaur against Pratap Singh and Pritipal Singh  brother-in-law of Preetam Singh  for a decree for rendition of account of the dealing in respect of the Jaora Slate Pencil Works and for appointment of a receiver.

facts.text: Pritipal Singh is brother-in-law of Preetam Singh.

anchor.surface_text: against Pratap Singh and Pritipal Singh  brother-in-law of Preetam Singh

facts.text: The plaint was amended to include a claim for dissolution of partnership.

anchor.surface_text: By amendment of the plaint a claim for dissolution of partnership was also made.

facts.text: Pratap Singh applied under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act 1940 for stay of the suit and the application was granted.

anchor.surface_text: Pratap Singh applied under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act 1940 for stay of the suit, and the application was granted.

facts.text: The Additional District Judge directed appointment of a receiver of the properties of the Jaora Slate Pencil Works at Pipliya notwithstanding the stay.

anchor.surface_text: But the Additional District Judge directed that a receiver be appointed of the properties of the Jaora Slate Pencil Works at Pipliya.

facts.text: An appeal was carried to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh against the receiver appointment order.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order an appeal was carried to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court held that a case was made out for appointment of the receiver.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that a case was made out for the appointment of the receiver.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court held that the application for receiver was maintainable without adjudicating Delhi Subordinate Judge's jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Court further held that having regard to the proceedings pending in the High Court at Delhi it was a case in which without adjudicating upon the jurisdiction of the Subordinate Judge at Delhi, the application for appointment of the receiver was maintainable.

facts.text: The only question argued in the appeal is about the jurisdiction of the Additional District Judge, Mandsaur to entertain the suit and appoint a receiver.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, with special leave, this appeal has been preferred. The only question argued in this appeal is about the jurisdiction of the Additional District Judge, Mandsaur to entertain the suit and to appoint a receiver.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the Civil Court at Mandsaur was competent to appoint a receiver until Delhi Court's jurisdiction is finally determined.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the Civil Court at Mandsaur was companypetent to appoint a receiver of the property until the question about the jurisdiction of the Delhi Court under s. 31  4  to entertain applications arising out of the order of reference is finally determined.

facts.text: The suit at Mandsaur relates only to the assets of the partnership at Pipliya within Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the suit filed at Mandsaur only relates to the assets, of the partnership at Pipliya within the State of Madhya Pradesh and does number relate to the properties at Bombay and Nagpur

facts.text: Arbitration proceedings relate to all assets of the partnership.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitration proceedings undoubtedly relate to all the assets of the Partnership

facts.text: Appeal fails and is dismissed with no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed. There will be numberorder as to companyts.

issues.text: The only question argued in this appeal is about the jurisdiction of the Additional District Judge, Mandsaur to entertain the suit and to appoint a receiver.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, with special leave, this appeal has been preferred. The only question argued in this appeal is about the jurisdiction of the Additional District Judge, Mandsaur to entertain the suit and to appoint a receiver. The relevant statutory provisions may in the first be numbericed.

issues.text: whether the order staying the suit under s.34 of the Arbitration Act excludes the jurisdiction of the Court to appoint a receiver to protect the subject matter of the suit

anchor.surface_text: An application for stay of the suit pending before the Additional District Judge, Mandsaur was made by Pratap Singh and it was granted. arguments.claim: Civil Court at Mandsaur competent to appoint receiver until jurisdiction of Delhi Court finally determined

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the Civil Court at Mandsaur was competent to appoint a receiver of the property until the question about the jurisdiction of the Delhi Court under s. 31 (4) to entertain applications arising out of the order of reference is finally determined.

arguments.claim: Suit at Mandsaur relates only to Pipliya assets not Bombay/Nagpur, allowing respondent unfair possession of other partnership properties via receiver order

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the suit filed at Mandsaur only relates to the assets, of the partnership at Pipliya within the State of Madhya Pradesh and does not relate to the properties at Bombay and Nagpur and that by the expedient of obtaining an order for appointment of a receiver Preetam Singh has managed to remain in possession of the properties at Bombay and Nagpur to the exclusion of Pratap Singh.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Singh has managed to remain in possession of the properties at Bombay and Nagpur to the exclusion of Pratap Singh. We cannot at this stage, decide whe

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot decide at this stage if suit relating only to Pipliya assets maintainable; remedy for other properties is separate proceedings

arguments.claim: Case made out for appointment of receiver

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that a case was made out for the appointment of the receiver.

holdings.text: the Civil Court at Mandsaur was competent to appoint a receiver of the property until the question about the jurisdiction of the Delhi Court under s. 31 (4) to entertain applications arising out of the order of reference is finally determined.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the Civil Court at Mandsaur was competent to appoint a receiver of the property until the question about the jurisdiction of the Delhi Court under s. 31  4  to entertain applications arising out of the order of reference is finally determined.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction of Delhi court disputed; civil court seized of suit entitled to preserve property pending final determination; normal resort to Delhi court but exception due to dispute.

holdings.text: the jurisdiction of the Court to pass appropriate orders for protecting the subject matter of the suit was not excluded. An application for appointment of a receiver could be granted notwithstanding the order of stay of suit under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: An application for stay of the suit pending before the Additional District Judge, Mandsaur was made by Pratap Singh and it was granted. But thereby the jurisdiction of the Court to pass appropriate orders for protecting the subject matter of the suit was not excluded. An application

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stay under s.34 halts proceedings but does not oust power to protect suit property via receiver under general civil jurisdiction.

holdings.text: the Civil Court which is seized of the suit was entitled to make appropriate orders for preserving the property which is the subject-matter of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: But so long as the jurisdiction of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Delhi to entertain the application for extension of time was in dispute the Civil Court which is seized of the suit was entitled to make appropriate orders for preserving the property which is the subject-matter of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.41 power for defined 'Court' does not exclude civil court in suit; applicable when jurisdiction disputed despite normal recourse to arbitration court.

holdings.text: We cannot at this stage, decide whether the suit in so far as it relates to the assets of the partnership at Pipliya alone is maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot at this stage, decide whether the suit in so far as it relates to the assets of the partnership at Pipliya alone is maintainable. The arbitration proceedings undoubtedly relate to all the assets of the Partnership

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not ripe for decision at this stage; separate proceedings available for other assets.

holdings.text: The arbitration proceedings undoubtedly relate to all the assets of the Partnership

anchor.surface_text: The arbitration proceedings undoubtedly relate to all the assets of the Partnership and if Preetam Singh, as contended by Pratap Singh, has remained in possession of the properties of the partnership at Bombay and Nagpur

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement refers disputes relating to partnership business across all locations.
